finalPattern.pattern_name: First-person confessional opener plus a blunt, negative verdict about a broadly relevant target (e.g., “I’m Sorry…”, “This New Artist Completely Sucks”) materially lifts TPS by sparking controversy-based curiosity and widening reach beyond core music-theory viewers.

evidence.title: I'm Sorry...This New Artist Completely Sucks
evidence.excerpt: Confessional + blunt verdict + withheld subject; 3.2x above assumed baseline TPS.

evidence.title: I Hate To Say It...Pop Music Is Broken
evidence.excerpt: Apology lead-in with broad negative judgment on 'pop music'.

evidence.title: Unpopular Opinion: Auto‑Tune Has Ruined Everything
evidence.excerpt: First-person stance + categorical negative on a widely-known tool.

evidence.title: I'm Done Pretending...This Mix Sounds Awful
evidence.excerpt: Confessional tone + blunt verdict; broad production angle.

evidence.title: I Can't Believe It...This Grammy Winner Is Terrible
evidence.excerpt: Ellipsis + strong negative judgment of mainstream subject.

evidence.title: I Was Wrong...This Band Actually Sucks
evidence.excerpt: Self-reversal + decisive negative verdict to drive curiosity.

evidence.title: I'm Sorry But This Song Stinks
evidence.excerpt: Confessional apology + blunt negative; broad pop-rock audience.

evidence.title: I Hate To Say It...Your Favorite Band Sucks
Unpopular Opinion: This Album Is Bad
evidence.excerpt: First-person framing + blunt verdict on a broad release.

evidence.title: We Need To Talk...This Era of Music Is Broken
I Don't Like This Trend in Pop
evidence.excerpt: First-person stance + negative appraisal of broad trend.

evidence.title: Real Talk...This Viral Guitarist Isn't Good
evidence.excerpt: Confessional + blunt verdict on a widely-seen subject.
